oai_dc:dc.dc:title: DNA barcoding of British mosquitoes (Diptera, Culicidae) to support species identification, discovery of cryptic genetic diversity and monitoring invasive species
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hernández-Triana, Luis M
Brugman, Victor A
Nikolova, Nadya I
Ruiz-Arrondo, Ignacio
Barrero, Elsa
Thorne, Leigh
Marco, Mar Fernández
Krüger, Andreas
Lumley, Sarah
Johnson, Nicholas
Fooks, Anthony R
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: invasive species
invasion genetics
genetic diversity
Diptera
Culicidae
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Correct mosquito species identification is essential for mosquito and disease control programs. However, this is complicated by the difficulties in morphologically identifying some mosquito species. In this study, variation of a partial sequence of the cytochrome<jats:italic>c</jats:italic>oxidase unit I (<jats:italic>COI</jats:italic>) gene was used for the molecular identification of British mosquito species and to facilitate the discovery of cryptic diversity, and monitoring invasive species. Three DNA extraction methods were compared to obtain DNA barcodes from adult specimens. In total, we analyzed 42 species belonging to the genera<jats:italic>Aedes</jats:italic>Meigen, 1818 (21 species),<jats:italic>Anopheles</jats:italic>Meigen, 1818 (7 species),<jats:italic>Coquillettidia</jats:italic>Theobald, 1904 (1 species),<jats:italic>Culex</jats:italic>Linnaeus, 1758 (6 species),<jats:italic>Culiseta</jats:italic>Felt, 1904 (7 species), and<jats:italic>Orthopodomyia</jats:italic>Theobald, 1904 (1 species). Intraspecific genetic divergence ranged from 0% to 5.4%, while higher interspecific divergences were identified between<jats:italic>Aedesgeminus</jats:italic>Peus, 1971/<jats:italic>Culisetalitorea</jats:italic>(Shute, 1928) (24.6%) and<jats:italic>Ae.geminus</jats:italic>/<jats:italic>An.plumbeus</jats:italic>Stephens, 1828 (22.5%). Taxonomic discrepancy was shown between<jats:italic>An.daciae</jats:italic>Linton, Nicolescu & Harbach, 2004 and<jats:italic>An.messeae</jats:italic>Falleroni, 1828 indicating the poor resolution of the<jats:italic>COI</jats:italic>DNA barcoding region in separating these taxa. Other species such as<jats:italic>Ae.cantans</jats:italic>(Meigen, 1818)/<jats:italic>Ae.annulipes</jats:italic>(Meigen, 1830) showed similar discrepancies indicating some limitation of this genetic marker to identify certain mosquito species. The combination of morphology and DNA barcoding is an effective approach for the identification of British mosquitoes, for invasive mosquitoes posing a threat to the UK, and for the detection of hidden diversity within species groups.</jats:p>
